Graphical abstract HMF production from glucose-based feedstocks via concerted catalysis strategy 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), derived from renewable lignocelluloses, has been certified as a vital platform molecule for biorefining process. However, it has been difficult to balance the factors (including HMF selectivity, cost, energy consumption, and environmental friendliness) involved in the production of HMF. Therefore, significant challenges still remain for producing HMF from abundant and cost-effective glucose-based materials efficiently. To address those challenges, various approaches have been developed in the past decade. Summarized in this review are key findings related to the exploring of efficient catalysts and the screening of solvents system. The recent advanced researches presented in the current review have been classified according to solvent type, including water, organic solvent, water/organic solvent, ionic liquid, organic solvent/ionic liquid. Special attentions have also been paid to the dehydration mechanisms of glucose, the effective strategies on the inhibition of undesired side reactions, and some common issues or synergetic effects among various catalytic systems. Keywords Glucose-based feedstocks dehydration 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural Concerted catalysis 1 Introduction For building a sustainable economy, the biorefinery are getting more attention, and several various bio-based compounds were recognized as the most vital building blocks for producing bio-based commodity chemicals and fuels by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) [1–4]. 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), a dehydrated product of hexoses, has an outstanding position in the DOE top list. The unsaturated structure (Scheme 1 , containing aromatic ring, aldehyde group and methylol) of HMF provides excellent chemical reactivity for various HMF involved reactions, and a variety of valuable products have been obtained by far (Scheme 1) [5,6]. HMF and its derivatives have vast potential applications in many aspects of our ordinary activities, such as flavors and fragrances, fuels, solvents, pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, as well as monomers for polymers, therefore, the preparation of HMF have been widely studied in the past decades of years [7,8]. Recently, in the researches of HMF production, fructose, glucose, cellulose, chitosan, and lignocellulose were mainly used as the feedstocks [9]. Although, in either homogeneous or heterogeneous reaction systems, high HMF yields can be readily obtained via the dehydration of natural fructose which, however, is mainly stored in edible biomass (honey, fruits, etc.), the total reserves are relatively low. As a result, consideration of fructose is not suitable as a raw material for large-scale production of HMF due to the constraint of resources [10]. As an illustration, Dumesic et al. launched a techno-economic analysis for the conversion of glucose (using Sn-beta/Amberlyst-15) and fructose (using dilute HCl) to HMF, in acetone/water mixed solvent. The results indicated that, glucose price was much more stable and lower than fructose. Despite the fact that using glucose as the feedstock required higher capital investment than using fructose, the minimum selling price (MSP, $ 1460/ton) of HMF produced from glucose was lower than that from fructose ($ 1710/ton) [11]. Cellulose, composed of glucose, is widely existed in natural lignocelluloses, such as forest and agricultural processing waste (sawdust, crop stems and leaves, etc.), leading glucose to be the most abundant hexose in the world [12]. Therefore, glucose-based materials (GBMs, including glucose, cellulose, starch) have been considered as ideal raw materials for large-scale preparation of HMF. However, the reaction networks of dehydrating GBMs to HMF are complicated, which involves several consecutive reaction steps including the hydrolysis of polysaccharide, the isomerization of glucose to active intermediates (reversible step, upon the presence of Lewis acid or Brønsted base catalyst), and the dehydration of intermediates to HMF. In addition, it is known that obtaining the high yield of final products is rather challenging in a multi-step organic reaction [13]. During the GBMs-to-HMF conversion, the stable supramolecular structure of cellulose makes the hydrolysis of cellulose to glucose difficult; the stable aldopyranose structure of glucose makes its dehydration into HMF difficult as well. Moreover, the high chemical activity of HMF and related reaction intermediates also facilitate undesired side-reactions in thermo-acidic environments (Scheme 2 , such as the self-condensation of glucose or intermediates, the fragmentation of glucose or intermediates, the elimination reaction of intermediates to form furfural, the cross-polymerization between furfural and HMF, and the crosslinking polymerization between HMF and intermediates, the rehydration of HMF to form levulinic acid). Therefore, converting GBMs to HMF is much more difficult than fructose dehydration [14,15]. The process of acid-catalyzed GBMs dehydration induces a number of undesired side reactions, resulting in low selectivity of HMF. The reactant containing poly hydroxyl groups without selective interaction with catalysts is one of the prime reasons [16]. Therefore, based on the above reasons, the optimization of reaction conditions, and rational design of catalyst properties have been considered as promising ways for preventing yield loss of HMF from further condensation or degradation of the substrates, key intermediates and HMF [17]. However, the relevant work still remains challenging. Given that HMF is unstable in reaction solution, protection strategy has also been studied in order to improve dehydration efficiency, and inactivate reactive functional groups of HMF (e.g. aldehyde and hydroxyl groups) to inhibit side reaction [18]. For example, Shuai and Pan directly produced HMF-acetone adducts from carbohydrates in acetone-containing solvent system, although this process was irreversible, the products were identified as hopeful jet fuel precursors [16]. Alternatively, producing 5-(halomethyl)furfurals (XMFs) from carbohydrates (HMF is one of desired intermediates in such process), XMFs generally have better stability and hydrophobicity than HMF, and these make it easier to isolate XMFs from reaction solutions [19]. In 2013, Putten et al. provided a comprehensive overview of the progress of the preparation of HMF and its derivatives, and the following updates of this field were given by many researchers, including in 2014 by Zhang, Abu-Oma, in 2015 by Mukherjee, and in 2018 by Elumalai [8,20–23]. While many efforts have been made on efficient production of HMF from GBMs by researchers, and some meaningful results were obtained, an economical, reliable large-scale production line has not yet been built. Finding an available approach for efficient production of HMF from GBMs is still in high demand. Therefore, the review consisting of updated literatures will benefit researchers in designing more efficient catalytic systems. Targeting on achieving relatively high HMF yields using GBMs as starting materials by a thermal-catalytic process, this review mainly summarizes recent advances in the synthesis of efficient catalyst and screening solvents system. Special attention is paid to the dehydration mechanisms of various catalytic systems and effective strategies on the inhibition of undesired side reactions. The key findings summarized herein will benefit the research related to exploring various methods for preparing HMF with high efficiency. 2 HMF preparation mechanisms Studying and clarifying acid-catalyzed glucose-to-HMF conversion mechanism is conducive to constructing a highly efficient catalytic system. Overall, HMF is obtained via elimination of three water molecules in glucose. Based on experimental and numerical simulation results, several different mechanisms have been proposed in the literature, mainly including acyclic, cyclic, and acyclic/cyclic combination pathways. As shown in Scheme 3 , for the acyclic pathways, glucose was first isomerized into active intermediates through Lewis acid-catalyzed 1, 2-intramolecular hydride shift or base-catalyzed 1, 2-enediol route, and then the HMF was finally formed through Brønsted acid-catalyzed two successive β-dehydrations and a ring closing elimination of a last water molecule [8,24–26]. For the acyclic/cyclic combination pathways (Scheme 3), glucose was also first transformed to cyclic ketofuranose intermediate through isomerization, and a tertiary carbonium cation was then formed via the hemiacetal dehydration at C2 of fructose intermediate, and subsequently, two consecutive β-dehydrations were occurred in five-membered ring to yield HMF [26–28]. Although the above two kinds of mechanisms have significant difference on the dehydration route of active intermediates, both of the two mechanisms hold the same view that glucose isomerization played a crucial role for improving HMF production efficiency. For the cyclic pathways, the pyranose ring would be directly transformed to a five-membered ring intermediate. Vlachos et al. proposed a cyclic mechanism for the Brønsted acid-catalyzed glucose dehydration, based on the results of DFT-based microkinetic model, kinetic and isotopic tracing NMR spectroscopy (Scheme 4) [29]. In this mechanism, the protonation triggered the transformation of glucose, and the removal of first water molecule from protonated glucose was the rate-limiting step. Because the activation of hydroxyl groups by Brønsted acid might occur at different positions of the pyran ring, several kinds of dehydrated intermediates along with various final products could be formed (HMF, furfuryl alcohol, etc.). This mechanism elucidates the reasons why the pure Brønsted acid catalyst system is relatively inefficient. To date, the dehydration of fructose does not involve ring opening is becoming consensus among researchers, but for glucose-to-HMF conversion, the routes of glucose isomerization and active intermediates dehydration are still elusive [28,30,31]. Further efforts should be made to find specific proof of the dehydration kinetics. 3 Efficient conversion of GBMs to HMF in aqueous systems In an efficient catalytic system, it is hard to rank the solvent, acidity of catalyst, and other factors in the order of its importance for achieving a high HMF yield. To emphasize the significance of solvent, the relevant catalytic systems summarized herein are classified by solvent type. Due to the differences of various solvents in polarity, boiling point, self-stability, solubility to substrates, and interactions with substrates and catalysts, solvents have important effects on conversion of GBMs to HMF conversion. So far, three kinds of liquid solvents have been studied in HMF production process: water, organic solvent and ionic liquids (including deep eutectic solvents). Additionally, may be because the combined solvent mixtures could integrate the advantages of different kinds of solvent, numerous co-solvents systems relevant to HMF production have been reported, including mutually soluble organic solvent/water system; immiscible biphasic organic solvent/H2O system; mixed organic solvents; organic solvent/ionic liquid. Based on the summary of published studies, the feasibility of various kinds of solvents for large-scale production of HMF is compared in Table 1 [20]. Because of the low cost and environment friendliness, water, the real “green solvent”, was used early as solvent for HMF preparation. However, no matter what substrates were used, the HMF yields in aqueous phase system were relatively low, and it is not easy to achieve a yield approach to 50 % [6]. The reaction rates of GBMs dehydration in pure aqueous phase were much slower than in most organic solvents, the stability of HMF is weak in water, and the solubility of water to HMF is relatively good, thus leading the selectivity to HMF is low, and the formed HMF is easy to be further degraded [17,20]. Additionally, for many Lewis acid catalysts, such as zeolite catalysts, their Lewis acid sites would coordinate with water to form Lewis acid-base adducts [32], and thus resulting in the deactivation of acid sites relevant to glucose isomerization. Nakajima et al. reported the dehydration of glucose to HMF over H3PO4 modified Nb2O5 in aqueous solvent, after reacting at 120 ℃ for 3 h, a HMF yield of 48 % was provided [33]. The NbO4 tetrahedra of Nb2O5 acted as Lewis acid sites, and it remained stable catalytic activity, though the formation of NbO4-H2O adducts in hydrothermal environment. Saravanan et al. hydrothermally synthesized a large-pore mesoporous zirconium phosphate (m-ZrPO) using P123 as a template. The strong Lewis acid and basic sites of m-ZrPO promoted glucose isomerization, and weak Brønsted acid sites catalyzed fructose intermediate dehydration, with the Brønsted to Lewis acid ratio (abbreviated as B/L ratio) of 0.29, reaching a maximum HMF yield of 46.6 % with glucose conversion of 83.8 % [34]. Wu et al. prepared a Ni-doped glucose-based carbon catalyst (Nin/CS) via consecutive hydrothermal/pyrolysis treatments [35]. The interaction between abundant hydroxyl groups and CC double bonds in Nin/CS endowed the formation of hydrogen bonds, which displayed electrophilic characteristics and acted as Lewis acid sites. The metallic Ni embedded in carbon skeleton led to an obviously enhancement on the total acid content and strength in Brønsted acid sites (carboxyl functional groups), and meanwhile a decrease in the Lewis acidic sites. The depolymerization of cellulose was conducted in sole aqueous solvent under hydrogen atmosphere, and the Nin/CS with B/L ratio of 0.56 gave a high HMF yield of 85.0 % at 200 ℃ for 60 min. Even merely under harsh hydrothermal conditions, a considerable amount of cellulose would be directly degraded, but with poor ideal products selectivities, while adding proper catalyst could improve the situation. In another study, glucose was reported to be effectively converted to HMF (93.0 %) over sulfonated graphitic carbon nitride in hot water (200 ℃). The concentration of Brønsted basic sites brought by nitrogen species was much higher than that of acidic sites, and these base sites was responsible for catalyzing glucose isomerization (Fig. 1 ). The sulfonic acid groups grafted were highly effective in catalyzing the dehydration of fructose [36]. Generally, the high reducing gas pressure and high temperature are well known in facilitating the cellulose dissolution and hydrolysis, and thus raising reaction rate. However, these harsh reaction conditions placed strict requirements on the reactor and increase the risk of experiments. 4 Efficient conversion of GBMs to HMF in organic solvent systems 4.1 Pure organic solvent systems The use of organic solvents in lignocellulose conversion reactions can bring high rates and improved selectivities, many polar aprotic solvents, including γ-valerolactone (GVL), dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO), tetrahydrofuran (THF), dimethyl formamide (DMF), dimethyl acetamide (DMA), acetone, 1, 4-dioxane, and N-methyl pyrrolidinone (NMP) have been investigated for furanic products production [20,37]. However, the undesired side reactions can also be facilitated in organic solvent, so it is still difficult to obtain an ideal HMF yield in a sole organic solvent, advanced catalytic systems using sole organic solvent are merely slightly more than those using pure aqueous solvent. By virtue of their solubility and reaction efficiency, DMSO and GVL are the most commonly used solvent for GBMs dehydration. For example, Zhang et al. reported glucose dehydration in pure GVL using SAPO-34 (0.584 mmol/g of total acid sites) as the catalyst, a high HMF yield of 82.2 % was achieved at 170 ℃ in 40 min, at a catalyst/glucose weight ratio of 2:1 [38]. Such high HMF yields should be ascribed to the good solubility of GVL to polymeric byproducts, since minimizing the deposition will help in maintaining the stability of the catalyst (GVL is a novel green bio-based furanic solvent, it could be synthesized by hydrogenation of LA and levulinic acid esters, or consecutive hydrogen transfer and ring opening reactions of furfural or furfuryl alcohol [39]); moreover, the rehydration of HMF to levulinic acid (LA) was inhibited in such system. Mellmer et al. thought that GVL can reduce the activation energy in the liquid phase reaction process; the stability of protons related to the protonated transition state is affected by GVL, which can improve reaction rate of the conversion of fructose or fructose intermediate (from glucose isomerization) to HMF [16,37]. Wang et al. synthesized cerous phosphate (CPx, x represented hydrothermal temperature) to produce HMF from glucose in DMSO, and the CP120 with B/L ratio of 0.8 gave a maximum yield of 61.0 % [40]. The higher hydrothermal temperature affected the surface Ce4+ amount of CPx negatively, causing the reduction of Lewis acid sites, and thus reducing the activity of CPx. Another study by Yan et al. proposed a process of glucose dehydration in DMSO using CeO2-sulfated zirconium (SZ)@SBA-15 as catalyst (B/L ratio around 0.8), SZ with Brønsted and Lewis acid sites was first loaded onto SBA-15 through layer-by-layer grafting, and then CeO2 (having basic sites) was introduced via wet impregnation methods [41]. Approaching to 70 % of HMF yield were obtained at 120 ℃ in 6 h, and this may be attributed to the co-existed base and Lewis acid sites, which promoted the glucose isomerization. Adding first main group metal halides into reaction systems was another way for improving HMF in sole organic solvent. Binder and Raines applied DMA/LiBr (LiCl)/CrCl2 (CrCl3) system for the conversion of cellulose and glucose to HMF, and pretty good HMF yields were obtained at relatively low reaction temperature (≤ 140 ℃) [42]. The loosely ion-paired halide ions in such solvent system were critical for rapidly and efficiently producing HMF. Moreover, using Zr(O)Cl2/CrCl3-DMA/LiCl system was also enabling 57 % and 42 % HMF from cellulose fiber and sugarcane bagasse [43]. Although the polar aprotic solvents with high boiling points have better solvation effect for HMF production, the isolation of HMF from such solvents usually needs energy-intensive procedures, it does not meet the requirement of sustainable and economic production. In order to alleviate the negative impacts of practically using high boiling solvents, the mixed organic solvents containing an eco-friendly solvent with low boiling point have been adopted for carbohydrates dehydration. Additionally, the utilization of mixed organic solvents may have a synergistic effect on integrating the respective merits of organic solvents, and play a positive role in promoting target product yield. Teimouri et al. synthesized nano-polyoxometalates/nano-ZrO2/nano-γ-Al2O3 through wet impregnation method for glucose dehydration, different solvents, including H2O, H2O/acetone, H2O/acetonitrile, H2O/THF, DMSO, acetone/DMSO, and ethyl acetate were compared, and acetone/DMSO showed the optimal performance, an optimal HMF yield of 60.1 % was obtained at 190 ℃ in 4 h [44]. Zhang et al. respectively applied halloysite nanotubes-supported sulfonated nitrogen-doped carbon and g-C3N4 supported UiO-66-type MOFs to dehydrate glucose, benefiting from the concerted catalysis of acid/base active sites, the HMF yields around 60 % were achieved in isopropanol/DMSO mixture [45,46]. Xiao et al. hypothesized that the isolation of acidic sites from water molecules may have a function in limiting the hydration of HMF [47,48]. To verify the hypothesis, superhydrophobic Brønsted acid catalysts (Fig. 2 ) were first synthesized via copolymerization of sodium p-styrene sulfonate and divinylbenzene including an ion-exchanging treatment, and such acid catalyst was proved to be effective in inhibiting undesired reactions of fructose dehydration (in THF/DMSO, HMF yield﹥99.0 %). Since isomerization step is crucial for efficient production of HMF from aldohexose, so superhydrophilic solid base catalysts (Fig. 2) were then prepared from copolymerization of 1-vinylimidazole, divinylbenzene, and N, N-methylenediacrylamide by the authors. Using the two catalysts together gave a pretty high HMF yield (95.4 %) in THF/DMSO, under a mild reaction condition. This study should be of certain reference significance to inhibition of undesired reactions during HMF production. Compared with Lewis acid, basic sites rarely promote undesired side reactions, therefore, the multifunctional catalyst with basic sites is increasingly used to dehydrate GBMs to HMF. 4.2 Mutually soluble organic solvent/water system The single phasic organic solvent/water systems have been studied more in recent years, since it was also found that adding water into some specific organic solvents could apparently suppress undesired side reactions and accelerate proton transfer, which was conducive to the dehydration of GBMs to HMF [49]. However, same as pure organic solvent system, because of the isolation difficulty of HMF in organic solvent/water monophasic system, only a few cases of acid catalyst were found to be specific for HMF production. Since the precise control of Brønsted and Lewis acidity on a multifunctional catalyst is somewhat difficult, in order to facilitate the study of the effect of catalyst acid properties on the preparation of HMF, different catalysts, which have definite Brønsted, Lewis acid sites, or basic sites, have been used together, such as Sn-beta/HCl, Sn-beta/Amberlyst-70, and hydrotalcite/Amberlyst-15 [13,50,51]. In our previous work, a p-toluenesulfonic acid-paraformaldehyde copolymerized resin solid acid (PTSA-POM), was combined with metal chlorides and Sn-beta zeolite, respectively, for conversion of GBMs to HMF in GVL/H2O [52,53]. Different metal chlorides were first screened, it revealed that AlCl3/PTSA-POM and CrCl3/PTSA-POM have much higher catalytic activities. Though the hydrolysis of metal ions in water can generate hydrogen ion, introducing PTSA-POM can still improve HMF selectivity, and it might indicate that external Brønsted acid species have a certain positive influence on inhibiting Brønsted acid-catalyzed undesired side reaction. Upon using PTSA-POM/Sn-beta, the HMF yields reached to 60.1 %, 19.8 %, and 18.4 %, respectively, from glucose, microcrystalline cellulose, and corn stover. The effect of water addition on glucose-to-HMF conversion was studied, it was found that introducing water could improve HMF selectivities, while too much or too little water in GVL/H2O mixtures did not give the optimal HMF yield. Excessive water in mixed solvents resulted in an increase of yields of fructose intermediate (meaning dehydration rate of fructose intermediate slow down), and the remained fructose intermediate suppressed further isomerization of glucose, thus leading a decrease of glucose conversion. Qi et al. combined novel Cr-ceramic and Sn-ceramic powder with dilute H2SO4 and HCl, respectively, to dehydrate glucose in DMSO/H2O. The relatively high HMF yields of 64.7 % and 63.9 % were obtained, which could be attributed to the synergistic effect between mineral acid and ceramic-based catalyst (containing Cr3+ or Sn4+ Lewis sites) [54,55]. To date, several competitive sole multifunctional heterogeneous catalyst-monophasic organic solvent/water systems have also been exploited. Ravasco et al. reported a HMF yield up to 70.0 % from glucose using CrCl3 modified Amberlyst-15 and tetraethyl ammonium bromide/water mixture as the catalyst and solvent [56]. Wang et al. deposited 12-phosphotungstic acid (H3PW12O40) onto aluminum (PWAl-200) by using a consecutive electric-flocculation/hydrothermal process, the interaction between H3PW12O40 and aluminum led to the formation of more Lewis acid sites (B/L ratio was 1.18) [57]. A relatively high HMF yield of 61.7 % was obtained in DMSO/H2O. Hara et al. used H3PO4 modified anatase TiO2 to selectively catalyze glucose dehydration in THF-water mixture (THF/H2O = 90/10), and the HMF yield achieved 80 % under high catalyst/glucose ratio (50/20 wt%). The Lewis acid sites on TiO2 were partially remained after H3PO4 treatment, and a new acid species of -O-PO(OH)2 was formed through the esterification between −OH groups on TiO2 and H3PO4, the synergistic effect between the two kinds of acid sites changed the poor catalytic activities of TiO2 [58]. Huang et al. designed and prepared phosphate-iron phosphate doped silica and phosphotungstic acid doped silica, the total concentration of acid sites on such SiO2-based catalysts was low (40−60 μmol/g), and the B/L ratios of the two catalysts were in the range of 0.5−0.9 [59,60]. The two catalysts showed fairly good catalytic performance for in acetone/H2O mixture, yielding 76.3 % and 78.3 % of HMF from glucose, respectively. This study demonstrated that high concentration of acid sites of catalyst did not necessarily lead to efficient production of HMF, and doping proper acid species onto an inert matrix might be an effective strategy in assembling efficient catalysts with balanced Brønsted-Lewis acidity. Otomo et al. prepared H-beta zeolite with high Si/Al ratio of 5.5 by seed-assisted method without structure-directing agent (SDA), the zeolite with B/L ratio of 3.6 exhibited favorable catalytic performance for glucose conversion to HMF (70.0 %) in the mixture of H2O/DMSO/THF [61]. Applying SDA-free method to synthesize zeolites could decrease the cost of using SDA (mainly are organic amine), the emission of NOx, and the crystallization temperature and time. Low boiling point organic solvents/H2O, such as THF/H2O and acetone/H2O, were considered as the most recent promising solvent system for the scaled-up production of furanic products, because the isolation and purification of HMF, and the recycling of low boiling point solvent can be implemented easily with relatively low cost. Due to the diversity of catalyst-solvent combination in monophasic catalytic system, the B/L ratio of those efficient acid catalysts did not show similar rules like higher than 1, or less. And these will make it difficult to develop a novel and efficient monophasic catalytic system. 4.3 Immiscible biphasic organic solvent/water system The biphasic binary organic solvent/water mixtures are the most popular solvent system for GBMs dehydration in the new century, and Dumesic’s group has made a great contribution on extending the application of biphasic solvent for the carbohydrate dehydration [62,63]. Most recent studies that have achieved ideal HMF yields used such solvent system, because of its natural character of isolating HMF from acid sites. There are two types of biphasic solvent systems: 1) composing of water and organic solvent that cannot be miscible with water; 2) composing of saturated NaCl aqueous solution and organic solvent (NaCl can improve organic solvent-water partition coefficient). As shown in Fig. 3 , when producing HMF in a biphasic solvent system, the reactions relevant to HMF preparation (hydrolysis, isomerization, and dehydration) are mainly proceeded in aqueous phase, and the most of HMF produced can be extracted to organic phase, while acid catalysts remain in the aqueous phase. MIBK (methyl isobutyl ketone)/H2O and modified MIBK-2-butanol/H2O-DMSO were early applied for HMF production, after that, various biphasic solvent systems, such as CH2Cl2/H2O-DMSO, alcohol/H2O, alkylphenol/H2O, MIBK/H2O-NaCl, THF/H2O-NaCl, and GVL/H2O-NaCl have been gradually developed for HMF production in recent years. Among these solvent systems, MIBK/H2O-NaCl and THF/H2O-NaCl exhibited unique solvent performance for the dehydration of GBMs to HMF [64,20]. 4.3.1 Homogeneous catalyst By virtue of good availability, homogeneous catalysts, including mineral acids (HCl, H2SO4), organic acid (sulfanilic acid, maleic acid, etc.) and salts (AlCl3, CrCl3, Hf(OTf)4, ZnCl2, NaHSO4, etc.) have been earlier studied in biphasic solvents (Table 2 ) [65–71]. Li et al. compared the differences in catalyzing glucose dehydration by HCl and H2SO4, using GVL/H2O-NaCl as the biphasic solvent. It was found that HCl exhibited higher performance than H2SO4 (Table 2, entry 1), such difference may be because the acid strength of HCl is higher than H2SO4 [65]. Additionally, compared with monophasic GVL/H2O, adding NaCl into dilute H2SO4 also significantly increased the HMF yields, proving again that chlorides ions’ well-known role of improving the dehydration of carbohydrates to HMF. Mineral acids are short of Lewis acidity, the random contact between acidic protons and compounds involving GBMs dehydration usually leads to low target product selectivity, therefore, the HMF yield obtained in this study was fairly good. In another study, a higher HMF yield (78 %) was achieved from glucose, using organic acid (sulfanilic acid) and biphasic 2-butanol-MIBK/H2O-DMSO as the catalyst and solvent [72]. Such Dumesic modified biphasic solvent could facilitate both the isomerization (catalyzing by base groups of sulphanilic acid)/dehydration reactions and the extraction of HMF to organic phase, and by contrast, only a low yield of 16.0 % was obtained in MIBK/H2O. Adding DMSO and 2-butanol immensely promoted the efficiency of glucose dehydration and HMF extraction. Aluminum and chromium salts, having strong Lewis acidity, their catalytic activities and mechanisms have been deeply studied. Choudhary et al. found that although the Cr species CrOH2+ in CrCl3 was effective for the isomerization of glucose to fructose (Scheme 5 a), the intrinsic Brønsted acid (formed by the hydrolysis of Cr(III) ion) was not selective in the HMF production, since it could also efficiently catalyze subsequent rehydration of HMF to LA [73]. Upon adding external Brønsted acid HCl, the selectivity to HMF was obviously improved, and a HMF yield of 59 % was achieved in THF/H2O-NaCl. The Lewis acid not only facilitate the glucose-fructose isomerization, but also promote the side reactions; in addition to being able to catalyze dehydration reactions, the external Brønsted acid also has a negative effect on the CrOH2+ concentration by shifting the chemical equilibrium of hydrolysis of Cr3+ cation, and thus going against the glucose-fructose isomerization. Therefore, based on the results of Brønsted-Lewis acid interplay, optimizing the amounts of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites is very important in reaching high HMF yield from GBMs. Swift et al. also studied the kinetic regimes of tandem reaction of glucose-to-HMF catalyzed by an aqueous CrCl3/HCl solution, and the results were in good agreement with those of Choudhary [74]. Hu and Abu-Oma et al. first produced HMF from glucose using AlCl3·6H2O and NaCl-THF/H2O as the catalyst and solvent, respectively, and a relatively high HMF yield of 61 % was reached at 160 ℃ in 10 min [75]. A mechanistic study of AlCl3·6H2O-catalyzed glucose dehydration was then conducted [76,77]. [Al(OH)2(aq)]+ species, derived from the hydrolysis of AlCl3·6H2O in water, could accelerate the ring-opening of glucose ([Al(OH)2(aq)]+ bound with glucose at the positions of the C1 − O and C2 − O), and thus initiates the hydride shift reactions (Scheme 5b). In addition, an insight into the reaction network was obtained through a systematic experimental kinetics study: THF promoted the formation of formic acid though the direct degradation of glucose; NaCl promoted the polymerization of ketofuranose intermediates, and restrained glucose-to-humins polymerization; intrinsic HCl from the hydrolysis of AlCl3 caused a series of side reactions, including degradation of glucose to FA, polymerization of HMF to humins, and rehydration of HMF to LA; [Al(OH)2(aq)]+ species was responsible for the degradation of HMF to FA; both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites were active for the polymerization of glucose/ketofuranose intermediates to humins (Scheme 5c). Dumesic et al. reported a catalytic system consisting of AlCl3/HCl catalysts and 2-sec-butylphenol/H2O-NaCl mixed solvents, for the conversion of glucose to HMF, organic phase extracted almost all of the HMF produced in aqueous phase (97 %), and a HMF yield of 62 % was obtained [78]. Furthermore, based on AlCl3/HCl-MIBK/NaCl-H2O system, Yue et al. launched glucose dehydration experiment in a slug flow capillary microreactor, and an enhanced HMF yield of 66.2 % was gained (Fig. 4 ). Such improvement in reactor facilitated mixing/reaction in the aqueous droplet, and the extraction of HMF to the organic slug, allowing the dehydration to proceed largely controlled by kinetic rules, having positive effect on reducing side reactions [69]. In addition to the widely studied salts of aluminum and chromium, there are several novel metal salts system have recently been proved to be effective. Yan et al. compared the activity differences of transition metal chlorides (TiCl3, VCl3, CrCl3, FeCl3, MoCl3, RuCl3) for cellulose dehydration in biphasic butanol/H2O-NaCl solvent [79]. The optimal HMF yield (83.3 %) was given by RuCl3 because of its moderate acidity in hydrothermal environment, while using other metal chlorides produced more byproducts, including levulinic acid and lactic acid. However, the use of high reaction temperature (220 ℃) and the high cost of RuCl3 limited its practical application, and it is known that higher reaction temperature (≥ 200 ℃) has a significant enhancement on HMF production. Similarly, assisted by high reaction temperature, promising results of cellulose depolymerization to HMF was provided in THF/seawater system with condition of catalyst free [80]. The chloride ions play important roles during the whole process of cellulose depolymerization to HMF. The chloride ions facilitate the formation of a small amount of acidic protons in hot sea water, which can catalyze the hydrolysis of cellulose and the dehydration of fructose intermediate. Moreover, the chloride ions can chelate with acyclic glucose intermediate, inducing the isomerization of glucose to fructose via a 1, 2-hydride shift route; the formed HMF can be easily extracted to organic phase from sea water. Directly applying seawater as catalyst and solvent provided a new alternative approach for sustainable mass production of HMF. To date, considerable progress has been made in the preparation of HMF using homogeneous catalysts. However, the free contact between homo-dispersed acidic sites and GBMs dehydration-related compounds in reaction solution leads to the formation of HMF and undesired byproducts at the same time, and thus resulting in the further promotion of selectivity to HMF becomes difficult [20]. Additionally, the disadvantages of running a homogeneous catalytic system are obvious, mainly including serious reactor corrosion problems causing by the strong Brønsted acidity, especially mineral acids; the relatively high difficulty of separating homogeneous catalysts from solvent; the generation of more toxic waste. These disadvantages increase the cost of using homogeneous catalysts for the scaled-up production of HMF. 4.3.2 Heterogeneous catalyst To address the issues related to the shortcomings of homogeneous catalyst, much attention has been paid to the development of heterogeneous catalyst. Applying heterogeneous catalyst can reduce the amount of waste being produced, alleviate the reactor corrosion, and more importantly, heterogeneous catalyst can be easily separated from solvents by filtration or centrifugation. The unique molecular architectures and porous structure render heterogeneous catalysts highly atom economical and chemoselective [23,81,82]. To date, constructing heterogeneous solid acid catalysts has been considered as an important means for the development of greener catalytic protocols due to their unique properties such as recoverability, reusability, and stability in biomass conversion process [83]. In the field of dehydrating GBMs to HMF, promising results have been achieved by using various kinds of heterogeneous catalysts including aluminosilicate-based catalyst, functionalized silica, modified metal oxide, metal phosphate, and carbon-based solid acid [23]. 4.3.2.1 Silica-based catalyst Aluminosilicate-based catalyst, such as zeolites and montmorillonite, have been widely studied in the furanic compounds production process, because of its shape selectivity and open channel structure [84]. The properties of thermal stability, acidity, and pore structure of aluminosilicate are governed by the structural dynamics, therefore, can be well tuned via different strategies, such as the insertion of metal sites, and the introduction of inorganic acid radicals or hierarchical pore structures into aluminosilicates (adding hierarchical structure-directing agent during the synthesis process or desilication via post alkaline treatment) [85,86]. By means of the above, multifunctional aluminosilicate-based catalyst with adjustable Brønsted and Lewis acidity can be readily constructed. Recent studies indicated the size and shape of the zeolite pores have only a slight effect on the intrinsic activity of the catalyst, but have a strong effect on the thermodynamic stability of the acyclic glucose and fructose intermediates adsorbed in the zeolite pores [87,88]. Upon dehydrating carbohydrates using zeolites with microporosity, the diffusion of carbohydrates is easy to be limited by small pore size of zeolites, and thus causing unacceptable results. Maireles-Torres et al. tested the catalytic performance of microporous zeolites (H-ZSM-5, H-Y) and micro-mesoporous zeolite (H-Beta, protonated L-type zeolites (LTL topology)) for glucose dehydration in MIBK/H2O, with the assistance of high concentration of NaCl or CaCl2, favorable HMF yields were provided by H-beta and H-LTL [89,90]. Peela et al. synthesized mordenite zeolite with mesoporosity using a seed-assisted method (template-free), the B/L ratio of the zeolite was nearly equal to 1, and a HMF yield of 66.0 % was obtained from glucose [91]. The above studies certified that mesoporosity of zeolites was in favor of improving its capacity for catalyzing glucose to HMF conversion. However, although some zeolites have mesoporous structure, their reactivities were also restricted by inadequate acid strength and concentration. Therefore, intensification studies have been performed on controlling the acid properties of zeolites, doping a second metal onto zeolites is a reliable method [84]. When integrating a second metal onto aluminosilicate, the second metal may occupy the framework position of aluminosilicate (metal-O-Si complex bonds, this is more likely to be achieved) or form extra-framework metal species, both of the two binding states can enhance the acidity and catalytic activity of parent aluminosilicate [86]. To date, different second metals (Nb, Fe, Cr), which possessed Lewis acidity in their states of ion or oxidation, have been inserted into H-beta zeolite via different protocols, such as a consecutive zeolite dealuminisation and impregnation, a simple liquid ion-exchange or wetness impregnation [92–94]. Since the framework position of parent beta-zeolite was less occupied by second metals, so the formation of extra-framework metal species was mainly responsible for the modification of acid properties of beta-zeolites. Generally, in these metal-doped zeolites, Lewis acid was initially increased as metal loading increased, after reaching a maximum value, it would start to decrease with further increasing metal loading; the Lewis acid sites was simultaneously more than Brønsted acid sites (B/L ratio was around 0.67−0.83). After modified by second metals, the zeolites showed improved catalytic performance for conversion of glucose to HMF (Nb-beta, 82.1 %, in MIBK/H2O-NaCl; Fe-beta and Cr-beta, 61.0 % and 72 %, in THF/ H2O-NaCl). In addition to beta-zeolites, Al and Nb-doped montmorillonites (Al-MMT, Nb-MMT) were recently found to be effective, and high HMF yields of 80.4 % (in THF/H2O-NaCl) and 70.5 % (in MIBK/H2O-NaCl) were respectively achieved [95,96]. The two catalysts were synthesized from calcium montmorillonite by ion exchanging with metal salts. In Al-MMT, the Al3+ and partially hydrolyzed Al−OH groups were the major active sites, and the concentration of Lewis acid were much high than Brønsted acid (B/L ratio was as low as 0.016). In Nb-MMT, the introduction of niobium into montmorillonite led to reduction in both total acid sites and acid strength, and forming niobium oxyhydroxide species (simplified as the [NbO(OH)] group) with relatively weak acidity. As both proton donor and acceptor, the [NbO(OH)] groups are the essential trigger in the conversion of glucose to HMF via classical isomerization-dehydration protocol (Scheme 6). Because silica has similar basic structures with aluminosilicate [SiO4], and the acid strength of silanol groups on SiO2 are weak, therefore, SiO2, especially mesoporous SiO2 (such as SBA-15, MCM-41) with an ordered pore structure, high specific surface area and thermal stability, are suitable for use as a catalyst matrix to provide elevated heterogeneity for doped acid species [97]. So far, Brønsted/Lewis acidity can be imparted by introducing heteroatoms (via in situ addition during the synthesis of silica or post-impregnation), organic functional groups (post-grafting) and acid radicals (post-impregnation). In-situ synthesis are usually applied in synthesizing metal-silica complex oxides, because embedding metals into silica framework and the formation of mononuclear MOx (metal is abbreviated as M, the MOx could act as Lewis acid) are more likely to be enabled. Additionally, M–OH–M and M–OH–Si bridges, which could provide acidic protons, might form between MOx groups itself or with SiO4 on silica [98]. Jiménez-Morales et al. in situ doped aluminum onto MCM-41 through a sol-gel method, and Al/MCM-41 exhibited relatively good catalytic performance for HMF production (63 %) in MIBK/H2O-NaCl [99]. The results from X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) revealed that a fraction of aluminum was inserted into the siliceous structure with tetrahedral coordination, and the increase of acidic sites in Al/MCM-41 could be ascribed to the presence of such Si–O–Al bond. Wang et al. used SiO2-Al2O3 (AlSiO, prepared by sol-gel method) and THF/ H2O-NaCl as the catalyst and reaction medium, after reacting at 160 °C for 1.5 h, using AlSiO-20 (Si/Al ratio of 20) provided 63.1 % and 35.0 % of HMF yields from glucose and cellulose [100]. The possible structure acid sites is presented in Fig. 5 , the total acid of AlSiO-20 was 523 μmol/g, and the B (Al–OH–Si bridges)/L (three-coordinated Al species) ratio was 0.26. The authors further regulated the Brønsted/Lewis acidity of the catalyst by altering the Si/Al ratio in the composite, the catalyst calcination process, and introducing Nb or Na species, to clarify the effect of catalyst acid properties on the production of HMF [101]. It was found that the Lewis acid site could promote glucose isomerization, while the Brønsted acid site not only adversely affected the effective conversion of glucose, but also promoted the aldol addition and condensation reaction of HMF. There is a good linear correlation between the ratio of weak/total Lewis acid and HMF selectivity, weak Lewis acid sites promote positive conversion of glucose to HMF, while medium-strong Lewis acid sites aggravate the undesired side reactions, leading to the formation of levulinic acid and humins. Peng et al. introduced Nb during the hydrothermal synthesis of SBA-15, and enhanced HMF yields (61.8 % and 50.7 % from glucose and cellulose) were enabled using Nb-SBA-15 in THF/H2O-NaCl. In common with other Nb-based catalysts, the framework and extra-framework NbO4 and Nb−OH−Nb bridges acted as Lewis and Brønsted acid, respectively, for glucose dehydration (B/L ratio of 0.17) [102]. 4.3.2.2 Metal oxide Metal oxides, especially some early transition metal oxides (including TiO2 and Nb2O5, etc), generally possess alkaline sites or water-resistant Lewis acidic sites (unsaturated coordination species, NbO4 and TiO4), and have traits of easy preparation and low cost, hence metal oxides were also widely used as catalysts for the production of HMF [23,103,104]. However, because of lacking an appropriate Brønsted acidity, the efficiency of directly using sole metal oxide to catalyze glucose dehydration was relatively low. Therefore, to meet the reaction requirement of efficient conversion GBMs to HMF, modified metal oxides were synthesized via various strategies: preparing mixed metal oxides; integrating phosphate, sulfate or other polyvalent anions onto metal oxides [23]. To date, various metal oxides, including ZrO2, TiO2, WO3, Nb2O5, Fe3O4, as well as Al2O3 have been studied, and among these oxides, TiO2 and ZrO2 have already exhibited superior catalytic activities for GBMs dehydration in biphasic solvent system [23]. Considering that metal oxides-containing system was short of proper Brønsted acidity, Fang et al. directly adding external NaHSO4 to ZrO2/THF-H2O system, NaHSO4 acted as salting-out agent and simultaneously provided H+ ions, after reacting at 190 ℃ for 60 min, a fairly high HMF yield of 86.5 % was achieved from cellulose [104]. Atanda et al. used two kinds of TiO2-based catalyst to achieve high HMF yields from GBMs. TiO2-ZrO2 (TZ) was prepared via a sol-gel process, and the acidity of mixed oxides increased with the increase of TiO2 content; phosphated TiO2 (P-TiO2) was prepared by calcinating ammonium phosphate treated titanium hydroxide hydrate, Brønsted acidity appeared on P-TiO2 (B/L ratio of 5.3) accompanied by a decrease in the Lewis acidity. TiO2-ZrO2/Amberlyst-70 combined mixture provided a high HMF yield of 74 % from glucose in biphasic system [105]; moreover, P-TiO2 exhibited excellent catalytic performance in various biphasic solvents, including THF/H2O-NaCl (from glucose: 83.4 %), NMP-THF/H2O-NaCl (from starch: 80.7 %), n-butanol/H2O (from glucose: 81 %), and 2-methyltetrahydrofuran-NMP/H2O (from sugarcane bagasse: 72 %) [106,107]. Silahua-Pavón further compared the effect of additives, such as HNO3, CH3COOH, NaOH and NH4OH on the acid properties of TiO2-ZrO2 (TZ, 50/50 wt%) synthesized [108]. Acidity analysis revealed that total acid sites for mixed oxides were obviously higher than that of sole TiO2 and ZrO2, and both the total acid and weak acid sites for TZ-C2H4O2 were the highest among TZ-HNO3, TZ-C2H4O2, TZ-NH4OH, and TZ-NaOH. Catalyzing by TZ-C2H4O2 in THF/H2O-NaCl under 30 bar Ar, an optimal HMF yield of 76 % was enabled from glucose. Till now, TiO2-based multifunctional acid catalysts were found to be effective for GBMs conversion to HMF in either monophasic or biphasic solvent, and these could be attributed to its balanced Brønsted/Lewis acidity [106]. Excepting TiO2-based catalysts, Hassan et al. constructed and used a magnetic Fe3O4@SiO2-SO3H to dehydrate glucose in MIBK/H2O, a HMF yield approaching 70 % was achieved at 140 ℃ in 24 h [109]. The authors thought that glucose isomerization should be catalyzed by the small portion of uncoated Fe3O4. 4.3.2.3 Metal phosphate Most of metal phosphates (abbreviated as MPO) are insoluble in water or organic solvents, and commonly possess Brønsted/Lewis acid sites, as well as basic sites. In addition, the synthesis of metal phosphates is relatively easy. Similar to zeolites (having open framework structure), the acidity and pore structure of MPO could be readily tuned by changing metal/phosphorous dosing ratio, chemical additives (second metal species, organic template), or using different synthesis methods, such as sol-gel-calcination and hydrothermal-calcination process [23,110]. Therefore, to date, a wide range of metal phosphates, including phosphates of iron (FePO), cerium (CePO), niobium (NbPO), zirconium (ZrPO), titanium (TiPO), aluminum (AlPO), magnesium (MnPO), tin (SnPO), vanadium (VPO), and hafnium HfO(PO4)2 have been studied in the synthesis of HMF from GBMs [111–117]. In general, for the metal phosphates, the Brønsted acid sites are derived from hydroxyl groups (Metal–OH or PO–H), and the strength of Brønsted acid sites is related to the electronegativity of the metals; as for Lewis acid sites, it includes phosphate-bound metal sites (M–O–P) and coordination unsaturated sites of metal (same as Lewis acid sites in oxides) [111]. Additionally, the dissolution and further hydrolysis (forming acidic protons and metal hydroxyl species) of some metal species could also provide Brønsted/Lewis acidity for catalyzing GBMs dehydration [115]. Due to the natural difference among metals, metal phosphates exhibited differential performance for selective production of HMF. Ordomsky et al. earlier disclosed the Brønsted/Lewis acid species in AlPO, TiPO, ZrPO, and NbPO, and their catalytic behaviors on the conversion of glucose to HMF; and found that the activities of these phosphates decreased in the order: NbPO﹥ZrPO﹥TiPO﹥AlPO [111]. Although the HMF yields in this study were relatively low, it had a referential significance for the latter improvement of phosphates. In the following studies, Xu et al. reported favorable HMF yields of 59.0 % and 44.0 % from glucose and cellulose, using inexpensive MnPO as the catalyst in THF/H2O-NaCl [115]. The authors hold that the required acidity was originated in the hydrolysis of dissolved MnPO in solvent. In a similar study, using commercial FePO offered a HMF yield of 49.5 % from cellulose, and such phosphates acted like a “slowly-released drugs”, continuously providing active ingredients for the reaction [116]. In contrast, by changing molar ratio of KH2PO4/HfCl4 (0–2), Cao et al. prepared a series of amorphous HfO(PO4)x via a coprecipitation-calcination process [117]. The specific surface area, pore volume, and Brønsted acidity increased as the increase of KH2PO4/HfCl4 dose ratio. In THF/H2O-NaCl, HfO(PO)2 with B/L ratio of 0.2 showed best activity for producing HMF among HfO(PO4)x, fairly high HMF yields of 69.8 % and 90.5 % were achieved from cellulose and glucose, while relatively low yield of 18.6 % was obtained from corn stover under harsh reaction conditions (190 ℃, 4 h). This may indicate that the Brønsted acid sites in HfO(PO)2 were too weak to entirely depolymerize corn stover, but such weak Brønsted acid site was sufficient to catalyze dehydration reaction. However, HfCl4 is expensive, it is unaffordable to large-scale produce HMF using Hf-based catalysts. 4.3.2.4 Heteropoly acid Heteropolyacids, especially H3PW12O40, possessing attractive characteristics of strong Brønsted acidity and high proton mobility, thermal stability, well-defined structure, and accepting and releasing electrons, have been widely employed in research and development for dehydration of hexose-based substrates [118]. However, heteropolyacids are soluble in aqueous and organic solvents, bringing difficulties in separating catalyst from solvent [119]. Therefore, in order to fabricate heterogeneous heteropolyacids catalysts with dual Brønsted-Lewis acidity, solid heteropolyacid catalysts were synthesized by reacting heteropolyacids with various metal salts (Ag, Cr, Cs, Fe, Ce, and Cu) and ionic liquids (including choline chloride), or supporting heteropolyacid on solid matrix, such as silica [18,23]. Moreover, the Brønsted acidity of solid heteropolyacid catalysts can be well regulated during the modification process. Fan et al. evaluated the catalytic capability of Ag3PW12O40 in the synthesis of HMF from glucose, this salt was synthesized by ion-exchanging between AgNO3 and H3PW12O40, and a high HMF yield of 76.3 % was achieved under mild reaction conditions in MIBK/H2O [120]. The promoted activity of Ag3PW12O40 could be corresponding to the reduction of Brønsted acid sites and strength, and the appearance of moderate Lewis acidity, which was caused by the introduction of Ag+. Compared with incorporating metal species, introducing organic groups not only regulates the acidic properties, but also modifies the wettability of heteropolyacids. Temperature-responsive group (choline ion, HOCH2CH2N(CH3)3+, Ch+) modified heteropolyacids are insoluble in cool solvent, while with the increase in temperature, the catalyst is gradually dissolved. This phase changing capability enables the catalyst to act like a homogeneous catalyst, thus overcoming the hurdle of surface reaction and mass transfer limitations in heterogeneous catalysis. Lai et al. produced HMF from GBMs using a temperature-responsive choline chloride (ChCl)-modified H5CeW12O40 (ChnH5-nCeW12O40). By virtue of balanced Brønsted ([H4CeW12O40]−)-Lewis (Ce(Ⅲ)) acidity, ChH4CeW12O40 showed optimal catalytic performance in the synthesis of HMF from glucose (74.2 %) and cellobiose (70.2 %) in MIBK/H2O-DMSO biphasic system [121]. Zhang et al. synthesized a series of choline chloride (ChCl)-modified H3PW12O40 (ChxH3−xPW12O40, x = 1, 2 and 3) by easy coprecipitation without any other additive [122]. In MIBK (5 mL)/H2O (0.5 mL), the catalytic performance of ChxH3−xPW12O40 for cellulose depolymerization to HMF decreased in order: ChH2PW12O40 (75.0 %) > H3PW12O40 (49.1 %) > Ch2HPW12O40 (24.9 %) > HCl (18.0 %) > Ch3PW12O40 (12.2 %) > ChCl. The concentration of Brønsted acid decreased with the increasing of ChCl addition. Except acting like a homogeneous catalyst, ChH2PW12O40 having moderate Brønsted acidity that could reduce side reactions was responsible for its superior catalytic performance. Designing a temperature-response solid acid should be a promising alternative for biomass chemical conversion. Additionally, the authors found that using microwave irradiation could achieve the comparable results in much shorter reaction time, microwave-assisted heating could solve the accessibility issues of heterogeneous catalysis to a large extent [123]. In this study, upon using pure organic solvent (acetone, DMSO, THF, MIBK) and other monophasic organic solvent/H2O, or elevating the proportion of water in the MIBK/H2O, inferior HMF yields were obtained. It is known that an acid catalyst shows distinct catalytic performance in various solvent. However, till date, the insufficient understanding of the solvent effect has led researchers to make more effort on identifying effective catalyst-solvent combination. 4.3.2.5 Carbon-based solid acids Carbon-based solid acid (CSA) refers to a solid catalyst, which has carbon skeleton with acidic functional units, such as sulfonic acid and metal species. Therefore, polymer solid acid, acidic ion exchange resin, and sulfonated activated carbon can be categorized as CSA. Polymer solid acid and acidic ion exchange resin, possessing the merits of strong Brønsted acidity and easy large-scale preparation, have been extensively applied in acid-catalyzed reactions [124,125]. However, due to the lack of sufficient Lewis acidity in these catalysts, using such catalysts alone only afforded relatively low HMF yields from glucose. Therefore, to achieve favorable results, such catalyst was usually used together with a well-defined Lewis acid, as the above mentioned AlCl3, Sn-beta, and TiO2-ZrO2 [13,69,104]. Additionally, integrating metal species with Lewis acidity onto the carbon skeleton has also been realized, especially metal-organic frameworks-based catalysts, and promising results have been obtained using such catalysts [126]. Feng et al. respectively constructed sulfonic acid and amino group modified bifunctional Cr-based porous coordination polymers (PCP(Cr)-SO3H Cr and PCP(Cr)-NH2) (Fig. 6 ), and these catalysts with appropriate Brønsted/Lewis acidity and basicity exhibited favorable activities for glucose conversion to HMF in THF/H2O-NaCl [126,127]. Because of having excellent textural properties and electron conductivity, and certain chemical inertness, carbonaceous material including graphene, carbon nanotube, and amorphous activated carbon has been widely used as a catalyst support or even a catalyst for biorefinery [128,129]. Moreover, carbonized material is mainly derived from waste biomass, its preparation and application may largely decrease the so-called “carbon-footprint” of a biomass conversion process. During the synthesis process, these carbonized materials can be functionalized with organic groups (sulfonic acid and nitrogen-containing groups, etc., Fig. 7 ) and metallic sites (Ni, Nb, Sn, and Al, etc.) to enable special catalytic activity [130–133]. Carbonized material usually has some intrinsic Lewis acid sites, but it is not enough to effectively catalyze glucose isomerization, so most of published studies reported relatively low HMF yields using sulfonated carbonaceous material alone. Surprisingly, Nahavandi et al. recently found that a sulfonated oxidized activated carbon could effectively transform glucose into HMF (93 %) in THF/H2O-NaCl, and the catalyst have a fairly good recyclability [130]. Acid and base analysis indicated that this catalyst almost did not have Lewis acidity, but strong Brønsted acid (sulfonic acid group) and base sites (ketone and carbonyl groups) were formed during the consecutive oxidation and sulfonation process. As shown in Scheme 7, the authors hold that Brønsted acid-base sites synergy played crucial roles in promoting dehydration efficacy. This study provided a possibility for large-scale production of HMF using carbon-based solid acids. Excepting the above, the use of Lewis acid functionalized carbon catalyst for GBMs conversion to HMF was achieved earlier. Li et al. constructed a bifunctional niobia/carbon catalyst featuring Lewis (Nb2O5) and Brønsted acidity (−COOH), via a hydrothermal-calcination process using glucose and niobium tartrate as the feedstocks (B/L ratio of 0.9) [131], and possibly because the strong Lewis acidity of Nb2O5 facilitated the formation of byproducts, moderate results of 59.3 % and 53.3 % from glucose and cellulose were obtained. In the process of HMF production from GBMs with the catalyst having dual Brønsted-Lewis acidity, it is difficult to balance the activity requirement of facilitating isomerization and dehydration reactions, while suppressing undesired side reactions. In order to boost the development of CSA, new fundamental insights of devising carbon catalysts having strong Lewis acidity and/or basicity for glucose isomerization have been proposed. For example, Sn or Al-functionalized biochar has been devised by Yu et al., via an easy mixing-carbonization process, such catalyst was proved to be effective in isomerization of glucose to fructose [132,133]. In addition to using as solid acids for HMF production, considering that HMF separation via distillation have the shortcomings of high energy consumption intensity and possible HMF decomposition owing to instability, activated carbon and polymers are recently used as absorbents in solid-liquid adsorptive separation process, by virtue of their controllable properties of large surface areas, abundant microporosity, and hydrophobic surface [134]. Compared with distillation, such separation process is more suitable and economical for compound (including HMF) with low stability at bubble point [135]. Due to the excellent capability in isolating HMF from acidic environment, most of recently reported advanced catalytic results applied biphasic organic/H2O (NaCl) as the reaction medium. But this cannot be all attributed to solvents, heterogeneous acid catalysts with moderate acidity also played a significant role. As summarized in Table 3, in an efficient biphasic system, the catalyst primarily contains weakly Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites, and the concentration of Lewis acid is commonly much higher than that of Brønsted acid. Besides, mesoporous structure of solid catalyst facilitating the adsorption and diffusion of reactants to acidic sites, has a positive effect on producing HMF. Conclusively, it’s the synergistic effect between multifunctional solid acid and biphasic solvent that leads to ideal experimental results. Among the current catalytic system, biphasic catalytic system is most likely to be used for large scale production. However, the dehydration reactions in aqueous phase needs relatively high reaction temperature and time even with the presence of NaCl, and thus increasing the production cost. Moreover, there is still a long way to go in dealing with the issues of catalyst separation (homogeneous catalyst), large-scale synthesis of catalyst (solid acids), extraction solvent recycling, and HMF purification. 5 Ionic liquids By virtue of the properties of composition tunability, low volatility, high ionic conductivity, and strong solubility capacity, ionic liquids (ILs), as well as deep eutectic solvents (DESs, Both ILs and DESs are ionic salts with relatively low melting point, have similar physico-chemical properties) have been gradually used as the solvents for organic chemical reactions since the new century, especially ILs, because cellulose solubility in ILs is relatively good, it showed unique solvent activities for the depolymerization of cellulose to HMF with the aid of acid catalysts [6,136]. Since there are a wide range of combinations between cations and anions (including acidic anions), so a large number of ILs/acidic ILs have been prepared to date, and a wide range of acid catalysts combined with ILs composing of 1-alkyl-3-methylimidazolium cations and halides/hydrogen sulphate/methylsulfate/tetrafluoroborate/ trifluoromethanesulfonate anions could afford relatively optimal results [137,138]. As shown in Table 4 , among many different acid catalysts, chromium-based catalyst exhibited particular activities for HMF production in ILs. Zhao et al. earlier applied 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride [EMIM]Cl as the solvent for the conversion of glucose to HMF [149]. The catalytic performance of a series of metal chlorides were tested, it was found that CrCl2 and CrCl3 were more active, a relatively high HMF yield (70 %) was achieved at low reaction temperature (100 ℃). As shown in Scheme 8, further mechanism study verified the consecutive isomerization-dehydration reaction pathway. Dyson et al. further used CrCl2 to produce HMF in different imidazolium-based ILs (Fig. 8 ), an unprecedented HMF yield of 92.0 % was reached from glucose using IL4 and [C2OHmim]Cl, and relatively high yields were also obtained from cellulose in the mixtures of IL4 and IL9 [150]. NMR studies were used to clarify the enhancement mechanism, ILs containing a hydroxyl group can interact with glucose via hydrogen bonds, the CO bond were then weaken and activated, and thus reducing the activation energy of sub-reactions of glucose dehydration; the −CH2CH2Ph group in IL4 facilitated the ring-closing of acyclic fructose, which had a function on suppressing humins formation; The sulfonic acid group presented in IL9 promoted cellulose hydrolysis and subsequent dehydration. Tyagi et al. first prepared H2SO4-treated activated carbon (ACS), different metals, including chromium, aluminium, iron, copper, and zinc were immobilized on ACS. Using Cr-ACS in 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride ([BMIM]Cl)/H2O exhibited optimal performance (69.9 % HMF) for cellulose depolymerization [151]. Water in the reaction system was facile for improving HMF yield and reducing reaction time. In addition to chromium-based catalysts, using other kinds of catalysts, such as zeolites, metal phosphate, and carbon-based catalyst in ILs also exhibited promising results, and there are generally have synergistic effect between catalysts and ILs, which is in favor of promoting the conversion of GBMs to HMF. Qi et al. used concentrated H2SO4-sulfonated corn stalk-derived carbon to catalyze corn stalk depolymerization to HMF in [BMIM]Cl, reaching an optimal yield of 44.1 % at 150 ℃ in 30 min [152]. Yao et al. achieved 87.2 % and 68.2 % of HMF from glucose and cellulose, respectively, in 1-methyl-3-ethyl imidazolium bromide ([EMIM]Br) using sulfonated poly(phenylene sulfide) (SPPS) [153]. The interaction between [EMIM]Br and SPPS had a function of stabilizing the transition states and dehydration intermediates. The sulfonic acid groups of SPPS with strong Brønsted acidity not only acted as a proton-donor in dehydration, but also acted as a conjugated base for accepting proton in isomerization. Hou et al. found that tin phosphate (SnPO) interacted with [EMIM]Br was proved to be effective in the production of HMF, a yield of 58.3 % was obtained even in high glucose loading concentration (20 wt%) [154]. The tetra-coordinated Sn4+ sites and [EMIM]Br (possessing acidic proton at the C2 of the imidazole ring) were responsible for converting glucose into fructose via isomerization and dehydrating glucose to HMF, respectively. Ju et al. produced HMF from glucose using aluminum oxide, which was synthesized by alkaline treatment of commercial neutral aluminum oxide, with low Brønsted acidity and high Lewis acidity (B/L ratio around 0.16) [155]. A yield of 49.7 % was obtained in [EMIM]Br, and higher than that of using EMIMBr/AlCl3 system. Generally, compared with organic or aqueous solvent, ILs are better at processing the systems with higher concentration. Mamo et al. used NH4Cl-treated mordenites (mild dealumination) to catalyze glucose conversion to HMF, the 1 M NH4Cl treatment resulted in the increase of either Brønsted or Lewis acidity (B/L ratio around 2). The modified mordenites showed an optimal catalytic performance for HMF production (64.0 %) in [EMIM]Br [156]. Hu et al. compared a variety of zeolites (H-Y, H-beta, H-mordenite, and HZSM-5) for glucose dehydration in [BMIM]Cl, and H-beta (Si/Al ratio of 25) showed better catalytic activity (giving 50.3 % of HMF yield) [157]. The unsaturated coordinated Al in H-beta provided Lewis acidity for glucose isomerization, and H-beta ion-exchanged with EMIM+ released proton for fructose dehydration (Fig. 9). For zeolites-like catalyst, compared with that of using in a biphasic solvent, their mesoporosity plays an enhanced role in ILs, and these could be imputed to the hindrance of products diffusion, which caused by the rapid adsorption and strong interaction of ILs with zeolites. ILs containing halide anions of Cl− or Br− were widely used as solvents in the dehydration of carbohydrates. During the process of transforming fructose to HMF in organic solvents, chloride ions with highly localized negative charge presented in solvent can approach and stabilize protonated transition states, and we may hold that, upon producing HMF in ILs-containing system, halide anions of ILs also have similar effects [158]. Not merely using as the solvent, after modifying with acidic groups, ILs can also act as a solid acid catalyst [137,159]. For example, Zhao et al. synthesized a series of [1-aminoethyl-3-Methylimidazolium]-H3PW12O40 hybrid catalysts ([MimAM]nH3-nPW12O40, n = 1–3) via ion exchange method. The catalysts had adjustable Brønsted-Lewis acidity, and [MimAM]H2PW12O40 showed optimal performance for glucose dehydration, affording 53.9 % of HMF yield in THF/H2O-NaCl [160]. Since no fructose intermediates were detected, the authors proposed a special acyclic reaction mechanism involved key intermediate 1, 2-enediol (Scheme 9). The synergistic effect of Brønsted-Lewis acid sites endowed [MimAM]H2PW12O40 with relatively high efficiency for glucose dehydration. The development of applying DESs as the solvent for biomass conversion lags behind than that of ILs, and its performance was inferior to that of ILs. DESs are generally synthesized by the reaction between hydrogen bond donor and hydrogen bond acceptor under mild conditions (< 100 ℃) [161]. Ammonium salts, especially choline chloride (ChCl), are the most widely applied hydrogen bond acceptors which can react with a diverse range of complexing agents, such as amines, alcohols (including carbohydrates), and carboxylic acids to form DESs mixtures. Using ChCl-based DESs (including sole ChCl) as the solvents could effectively catalyze the dehydration of fructose (at a high initial concentration) to HMF, while the strong intermolecular hydrogen-bonding interaction between HMF and ChCl further stabilized HMF (Scheme 10 a), thus reducing the possibility of a nucleophilic attack and inhibiting the occurrence of undesired side reactions [162]. However, the solvent activity of ChCl-based DESs for the conversion of glucose to HMF is relatively weak, especially when heterogeneous catalysts were used together. CrCl3 and FeCl3 still showed good catalytic activities, and HMF yields around 60.0 % were obtained from glucose in ChCl and/or ChCl-based DESs [163,164]. A molten mixture of choline dihydrogen citrate-glycolic acid was applied by Matsumiya et al., for using together with B(OH)3 (with tiny amount of water as a co-solvent), and a HMF yield of 60.0 % was obtained at 140 ℃ in 4 h [165]. In addition to being used as solvent, ChCl was also applied to construct solid acids for biomass conversion, as previously mentioned ChCl-modified heteropolyacid [122,166,167]. Moreover, it was found that ChCl functionalization apparently enhanced the activity of the zeolites (with moderate silica-to-alumina ratio of 80) for GBMs dehydration, and this could be attributed to the strong interaction between ChCl and zeolite that induced by the N atoms of ChCl (Scheme 10b) [167]. Although ILs and DESs have been regarded as efficient solvents for HMF production, there exists some hurdles in the sizable application of them for lignocelluloses processing, 1) high cost of starting reagents for synthesizing ILs; 2) lack of toxicological and biodegradability data; 3) susceptible contamination of ILs/DESs with polymer by-products; 4) difficulty of homogeneous catalyst separation and products extraction in ILs/DESs [6]. 6 Ionic liquids/organic solvent mixed systems In some circumstances, high concentration of ILs and DESs accelerated the formation of polymeric byproducts, and thus limiting the HMF yields. To improve selectivity, organic solvents were used together with ILs, and they were divided into organic solvent-ionic liquid miscible monophasic system and immiscible biphasic system. In monophasic system, the polar aprotic solvents have the capability of partially reducing humins formation; additionally, the viscosity of most ILs is very high, mixing with organic solvent could reduce viscosity, and may be benefit for the mass transfer between substrate and acid catalyst [168]. The biphasic system is analogous with the above water/organic solvent immiscible system, carbohydrates dehydration is proceeded in ILs/DESs-containing phase, and HMF formed was extracted to organic phase to reduce undesired side reactions [162]. Both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts exhibited favorable performance in mixed solvents of organic solvent and ILs/DESs (Table 4). Because of the enhancement effect of chloride anions on the biomass conversion, ILs with chloride anions were mainly used. Raines and Graham screened different boronic acids and the combinations of organic solvents and [BMIM]Cl for glucose dehydration. Using 2-carboxyphenylboronic acid together with [BMIM]Cl provided HMF in 21 % yield from glucose, further adding DMF, DMA, NMP, and DMSO (strong electron donors) as the co-solvents, significant increase in HMF yields were obtained [169]. Zhang et al. used AlCl3 to depolymerize cellulose, and the HMF yield of 54.9 % obtained in [BMIM]Cl (10 wt.%)/DMSO mixed solvent were higher than that in [BMIM]Cl or DMSO alone [170]. Tang et al. synthesized boehmite (γ-AlOOH) as the sole catalyst for the conversion of GBMs to HMF in [BMIM]Cl/DMSO mixed solvent. The results of Py-FTIR indicated that γ-AlOOH possessed many Lewis acid sites, but few Brønsted acid sites, and high HMF yields from glucose (61.2 %) and cellulose (58.4 %) were gained using γ-AlOOH as the catalyst [171]. Liu et al. proposed a cleaner protocol for the dehydration of corn stalk, tin and magnesium ion-loaded biochar (Biochar-Mg-Sn) was prepared and used as the catalyst, loading metal ions onto biochar could formed Lewis acid sites [172]. The combinations of different organic solvents and 1-allyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride [AMIM]Cl were tested over Biochar-Mg-Sn, and the [AMIM]Cl/isopropanol exhibited optimal performance, an impressive HMF yield of 63.5 % was achieved at low reaction temperature of 100 ℃. Jérôme et al. compared the specificity of the combination of different Lewis acids and ChCl-H2O/MIBK for glucose dehydration [173], their activity in decreasing order were: AlCl3, CrCl2, CrCl3 >FeCl3, CuCl2 > MgCl2, FeCl2 > MnCl2, BiCl3 > ZnCl2. In addition to organic ILs, inorganic molten salt hydrate (MSH, aqueous solution with high concentrations of inorganic salt, Csalt≥50 %) can be categorized as one kind of special ionic liquid, and its use for biopolymer depolymerization has been explored in the past several years. In MSH, the molar ratio of water to salt is similar to the coordination number of the salt cations, and the access of the salt cations to anions is shielded by a hydration shell; then, the water molecules inside the hydration shell are polarized to form acidic protons via ion-water interactions; finally, the anions of the salt promote the release of acidic protons (Fig. 10 ) [174,175]. In a practical case, Saha et al. reported the efficient saccharification of cellulose in LiBr/dilute aqueous H2SO4 system. The high efficient dehydration of glucose hydrolysate (HMF yield >80 %) was achieved, after adding AlCl3 and ethyl acetate as co-catalyst and extracting solvent [174]. 7 Conclusions and prospects To date, numerous catalytic systems have been developed for the conversion of GBMs to HMF; and the efficient production of HMF could be achieved through a rational design (including the construction of acid catalysts and solvents screening). However, there is still a significant gap between the efficient production of HMF in bench scale and the pre requisitions of commercial use of HMF. Following are some key concerns which should be addressed: (1) Some ideal results gained in lab recently have mostly used monosaccharides as the model compounds, which is still far from the success for efficient depolymerization and dehydration of cellulose or real lignocellulose as raw materials. Cellulose possesses stable three-dimensional structure and bundles with interlaced and complicated hydrogen bonds inside the molecule. Therefore, the solubility of cellulose in water and most organic solvents is poor, and the accessibility of acid sites towards glucosidic bond of cellulose is also rather limited, thus resulting in more difficulty in converting cellulose to HMF than dehydrating glucose. (2) It has been well documented that relatively high HMF yields were obtained using GBMs as the starting materials. However, the conversion mostly occurred in polar aprotic organic solvents with high boiling point, ILs, and organic solvent/H2O-(NaCl) biphasic system. Adopting the solvents of high boiling point or ILs systems to produce HMF in commercial scale appears to be difficult; whereas applying organic solvent system with low boiling point (including organic solvent/H2O-(NaCl) biphasic system) requires much work on improving catalytic efficacy and solvent recycling. Because of the complicated and hard-to-control nature of converting GBMs to HMF, there is prone to undesired side reactions, thus resulting in the unsatisfactory yield of target products. Both catalyst properties (such as acid strength and amount of acid sites, pore structure, surface functional groups) and reaction conditions (reaction temperature and time, solvent effect) have important influence on the reaction. However, the profound effects of those influencing factors have not yet been well understood. Therefore, in order to provide a better guidance for constructing a highly efficient and affordable catalytic system, the relationship among catalytic performances, catalyst properties, and solvent effect should be studied further. (3) Despite the dehydration of biomass to HMF and the conversion of HMF to valuable chemicals have been extensively studied, the research in the isolation and purification of HMF is inadequate. The lack of reliable HMF collection technologies has become the bottleneck for efficient production of HMF. More importantly, except for levulinic acid and its ester, without the success of HMF purification, directly producing downstream fine chemicals from GBMs is unlikely feasible. Therefore, exploring and developing advanced technologies for the separation and purification for of HMF should be prioritized. coredata.dc:description: 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), derived from renewable lignocelluloses, has been certified as a vital platform molecule for biorefining process. However, it has been difficult to balance the factors (including HMF selectivity, cost, energy consumption, and environmental friendliness) involved in the production of HMF. Therefore, significant challenges still remain for producing HMF from abundant and cost-effective glucose-based materials efficiently. To address those challenges, various approaches have been developed in the past decade. Summarized in this review are key findings related to the exploring of efficient catalysts and the screening of solvents system. The recent advanced researches presented in the current review have been classified according to solvent type, including water, organic solvent, water/organic solvent, ionic liquid, organic solvent/ionic liquid. Special attentions have also been paid to the dehydration mechanisms of glucose, the effective strategies on the inhibition of undesired side reactions, and some common issues or synergetic effects among various catalytic systems.
coredata.dc:title: Advance in constructing acid catalyst-solvent combinations for efficient transformation of glucose into 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural
